false 1198087 AAM-PDF MCAT 112658 112658 S2468-8231(22)00544-2 10.1016/j.mcat.2022.112658 Fig. 1 (a) Top and (b) side views of the optimized stable configuration of single B atom anchored on M3C2O2-x (M= Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W). Color code: metal in cyan, carbon in gray, oxygen in red, boron in pink. (c) Binding energy Eb (eV) of single boron atom anchored on M3C2O2-x. (d) Energy fluctuations and temperature variations versus AIMD simulation time for B@Mo3C2O2-x. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Two adsorption configurations of N2 on B@M3C2O2-x. (b) Adsorption energies of N2 on B@M3C3O2-x. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Linear relationship of N-N bond length (d N-N, Å) vs. Bader charge (Q *N2, |e|) of N2 absorbed on B@M3C2O2-x. (b) Computed partial density of states of N2 adsorption on B@V3C2O2-x, the Fermi level is set to be 0 V. (c) Charge density difference of the B@V3C2O2-x catalyst with the N2 adsorption through the end-on pattern. The charge accumulation and depletion were depicted by yellow and cyan, respectively. The isosurface value is 0.002 e/Å3. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Scaling relationship between ∆G* N2- * NNH and ∆G* NH2- * NH3 on different B@M3C2O2-x catalysts. The catalysts falling in the green region are the candidates that satisfy the screening criteria (0.70 eV). Fig 4 Scheme 1 Schematic illustration of the possible reaction mechanisms during the N2 reduction. Scheme 1 Fig. 5 Gibbs free energy diagrams for N2 electroreduction on (a) B@Nb3C2O2-x, (b) B@Ta3C2O2-x, (c) B@V3C2O2-x, (d) B@Mo3C2O2-x, (e) B@Cr3C2O2-x, (f) B@W3C2O2-x. The dominant pathway is highlighted by black line. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) Comparison of the adsorption Gibbs free energies for *H and *N2 on B@ M3C2O2-x(M=V, Cr, Nb, Mo, Ta, W)catalysts. Fig 8 Prediction of single-boron anchored on MXene catalysts for high-efficient electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction Ning Zhang Conceptualization Methodology Software Investigation Writing – original draft Mei-yan Wang Writing – review & editing Jing-Yao Liu Writing – review & editing ⁎ Laboratory of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical Chemistry, College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130023, People's Republic of China Laboratory of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry Institute of Theoretical Chemistry College of Chemistry Jilin University Changchun 130023 People's Republic of China Laboratory of Theoretical and Computational Chemistry, Institute of Theoretical Chemistry, College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130023, People's Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding author. The design of efficient catalysts plays an important role in the development of electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). 2D materials MXene can be used as promising catalyst substrates in NRR due to their superior chemical stability and conductivity. Here, using density functional theory calculations, 9 kinds of single-atom catalysts (SACs) B@M3C2O2-x (M = Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W) were constructed by anchoring electron-deficient non-metal boron atom on M3C2O2-x with one terminal-O vacancy. All SACs have good thermodynamic and electrochemical stability. The strong acceptor-donor interaction between B atom and N2 molecule leads to the activation of N2, thus promoting NRR. We adopted the screening strategies, including comparing the free energy of N2 adsorption, the free energy changes for the first and last electrochemical steps of NRR, and the selectivity of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Finally, five candidate catalysts (B@V3C2O2-x, B@Cr3C2O2-x, B@Nb3C2O2-x, B@Mo3C2O2-x and B@W3C2O2-x) were screened out. Starting from the end-on adsorption mode of N2, NRR proceeds through a mixed mechanism on each SAC. Our results show that these five SACs have excellent catalytic performance with the limiting potentials ranging from -0.32 to -0.48 V, which may be promising NRR electrocatalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Density functional theory MXene Single-atom catalyst Nitrogen reduction reaction Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction As one of the important chemical raw materials, ammonia (NH3) plays an important role in industrial and agricultural production, energy storage and conversion. At present, large-scale industrial NH3 is mainly produced by the Haber-Bosch process at high temperature (300-500℃) and high pressure (100-300 atm) [1–3]. This process not only consumes more than 1%-2% of the global annual energy generation, but also emits a large amount of greenhouse gas into the atmosphere, which aggravates the energy crisis and environmental pollution [4–5]. Exploring innovative approaches for ammonia synthesis to replace the traditional Haber-Bosch process is thus of great significance. Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (eNRR) has been considered to be a promising method to realize the green synthesis of ammonia under mild reaction conditions. However, due to the low proton affinity of N2, the commonly used transition metal-based NRR catalysts usually have high NRR limiting potential. At the same time, the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) accompanied in the NRR process leads to a low Faraday efficiency (FE) [6–12]. Hence, the development of electrocatalysts with high stability, good selectivity and high activity is the key to the promotion of electrocatalytic NRR technology, which is also a huge challenge. In recent years, a lot of research work on metal-based electrocatalysts for NRR has emerged involving various metal-based electrocatalysts, from nanocrystals to subnanometric metal clusters formed by a few atoms, and then to single atom. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted great interest in the field of electrocatalytic NRR because of their high atomic utilization and good catalytic activity [13–15]. As the support of SACs, two-dimensional (2D) materials such as graphene, boron nitride (BN), graphdiyne, have been widely studied in experiment and theory. Beyond that, MXene, a new class of 2D materials, is considered as promising catalyst substrates. MXene is composed of transition metal carbides, nitrides and carbonitrides, with the formula of Mn+1XnTx, in which M is transition metal element from groups IIIB to VIB, X is C and/or N, T is O, OH or F atom, and n=1,2 or 3. Since the first synthesis in 2011, a variety of MXenes have been successfully synthesized [16–17]. The unique properties such as high electrical conductivity, good thermal stability, adjustable surface terminations and corrosion resistance, make MXenes have broad application prospects in the fields of electrochemical energy storage, electromagnetic wave adsorption, and catalysis. A number of studies have shown that MXenes can be used as electrocatalysts in NRR due to their superior chemical stability and conductivity, and their catalytic activities can be tuned by functionalizing. Doping heteroatoms on its surface is one effective way to improve the performance of NRR. Various transition metal (TM) single atoms anchored on MXenes for NRR have been reported experimentally and theoretically [18–20]. For example, Liu and coworkers developed Au nanoparticles anchored on the surface of Ti3C2, which exhibited an outstanding NRR catalytic performance, with an ultra-high NH3 yield (30.06 μ g h − 1 m g c a t . − 1 ) and good faradaic efficiency (18.34%) [18]. Huang and coworkers demonstrated Ru atom supported on Mo2CO2 as NRR electrocatalyst had good NRR catalytic performance, with the limiting potential of -0.46 V [19]. Chen and coworkers reported that Zr supported on defective Mo2TiC2O2 possessed low barrier (0.15 eV) [20]. In addition to SACs with transition metal atoms as active centers, there are also SACs formed by doping non-metal atoms. Compared with TM-based SACs, non-metal-based SACs have high stability in aqueous solution. In particular, electron-deficient non-metal boron atom has also been widely investigated in NRR. The strong acceptor-donor interaction between B atom and N2 molecule leads to the activation of N2, thus promoting NRR [21]. B single atom supported on two-dimensional materials such as C2N (-0.15 V) [22], B/g-C3N4 (-0.20 V) [23], graphene (-0.31 V) [24] and MoS2 (-0.46 V) [24] are considered as potential NRR non-metal catalysts with high activity of NRR and NH3 selectivity, so they have attracted a lot of attention. Recently, Pan and co-workers theoretically designed and studied the B atom doped M2CO2 MXene with oxygen vacancy (M=Ti, Zr, Hf, V, Nb, Ta, Cr, Mo, W) for NRR [25]. The results demonstrated the B atom doped Mo2CO2 and W2CO2 catalysts with oxygen vacancy exhibit good catalytic activity and selectivity with limiting potentials of -0.20 and -0.24 V, respectively. Compared with TM doping, B doping can further improve the catalytic performance of M2CO2. M3C2O2 are widely studied MXene materials [26]. Gao et al. studied the NRR catalytic performance of TM atom (TM = Sc, Ti, Fe, Co or Ni) supported on Ti3C2O2 MXenes [27], and obtained the overpotentials of different TMs, ranging from 0.68 to 2.33 V. In view of the studies mentioned above, we wonder whether the B single atom can be stably anchored on the O-terminated surface of M3C2O2-x MXenes. How about their catalytic activity and selectivity for NRR? Therefore, in this work, we investigated the possibility of B-doped M3C2O2-x MXenes (B@M3C2O2-x, M=Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W) as potential NRR catalysts by density functional theory (DFT). The thermodynamic stability of all B@M3C2O2-x was first confirmed. Then, according to two-step screening procedure, six catalysts (B@M3C2O2-x, M=V, Cr, Nb, Mo, W and Ta) were screened out. Finally, the NRR mechanism of above six catalysts was studied in detail. Our results showed that B@V3C2O2-x is the most promising B-SAC for NRR, with the limiting potential of -0.32 V and good NH3 selectivity. This study not only provides a rational design basis of high efficient M3C2O2-x MXene catalysts, but also provides a new way to promote sustainable NRR. Computational details Spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [28]. The exchange-correlation energy was calculated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [29]. Projector augmented wave (PAW) method was adopted to describe the ion-electron interactions [30]. The DFT-D3 correction was used to account for the van der Waals (vdW) interactions [31–32]. A cutoff energy for the electron plane-wave expansion was chosen as 400 eV. 5×5×1 k-point grids was used for geometrical optimizations while higher density k-points of 15×15×1 was used for electronic structure calculation. The M3C2O2-x supported B SAC was constructed on the basis of 3×3 supercell of a single-layer periodic slab of M3C2O2-x through an oxygen vacancy generated at the O-terminal. A vacuum space of 15 Å in the perpendicular direction was applied to avoid the interactions between the adjacent periodic images. The energy and force convergence thresholds for the self-consistent field iteration were set to 10-5 eV and 0.02 eV/ Å, respectively. To simulate the solvation effect, the VASPsol code was employed in this work, where an implicit solvation model with a dielectric constant of 78.54 for H2O was adopted [33–34]. The free energy change ( Δ G ) of each elementary step of NRR pathway was calculated based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model proposed by Nørskov et al [35]. In this model, the chemical potential of proton-electron H+/e- pair in aqueous solution is related to that of half of the H2 gas molecule at standard conditions (p(H2) = 1 atm, pH = 0, and T=298.15 K), and Δ G is defined as Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G p H where Δ E is the reaction energy directly obtained from DFT calculations; Δ Z P E and Δ S are the changes in zero point energies and entropy at 298.15K, respectively. The vibrational frequencies of the gas phase molecules (N2, H2, NH3) are taken from the NIST database (http://webbook.nist.gov/chemistry/). Δ G p H is the free energy correction of pH, which can be calculated by the following formula: Δ G p H = k B T × pH × l n 10 . In this work, the pH value is set to zero. The limiting potential (U L) is determined by the equation U L = − Δ G max e , where Δ G m a x is maximum free energy change along the reaction pathway. Results and Discussion Structures and Stability of single B atom supported on M3C2O2-x On the surface of M3C2O2-x with O vacancies, different sites for B doping were considered, including O sites (O1, O2), two metal sites around O vacancy (M1, M2) and O vacancy (OV), as shown in Fig. 1 a. It is found that the O vacancy captures and stabilizes the B atom, which is bonded to the surrounding three metal atoms (M1, M2, M3). The optimized structures of B@M3C2O2-x (M= Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W) are shown in Fig. 1a and 1b (the corresponding lattice constants are given in Table S1). To evaluate the stability of B@M3C2O2-x, the binding energies (Eb ) of single B atom anchored on defective M3C2O2-x surface were calculated according to the following equation: Eb= Etotal - EB - EOV , where Etotal and EOV represent the total energies of B doped M3C2O2-x and M3C2O2-x, respectively, and EB is the energy of single B atom. It can be seen from Fig. 1c that the Eb values are between -5.6 eV (Ta3C2O2-x) to -2.63 eV (Ti3C2O2-x), indicating that the binding strength between the doped B atom and MXene is very strong. On the other hand, single TM atoms are prone to aggregate into clusters or bulk phases. In order to verify the feasibility of the experimental synthesis of the B@M3C2O2-x catalyst, the formation energies (E f ) of SACs were calculated by the formula E f = E B @ 3 C 2 O 2 − x − E M 3 C 2 O 2 − x − μ B , where E B @ M 3 C 3 O 2 − x and E M 3 C 2 O 2 − x are the total energies of B@M3C2O2-x and defective M3C2O2-x, respectively, and μ B is the chemical potential of B atom calculated from its corresponding bulk structure. According to this definition, the more negative Ef is, the more stable the catalyst is. The formation energies of B@M3C2O2-x given in Fig. S1 are found to be positive (ranging from 0.51 to 3.36 eV), suggesting that the supported single B atoms tend to aggregate. However, note that for the Pt SAC loaded on Ti3-xC2Oy successfully synthesized in the experiment, its Ef was calculated to be 6.78 eV [36], which is much larger than that of B@M3C2O2-x, thus indicating that these catalysts are promising to be synthesized by experiments. Furthermore, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were conducted at 400 K for 10 ps to further evaluate the stability of all these nine B@M3C2O2-x. Fig. 1d and Fig. S2a-h show the total energy and temperature variations against time for B@M3C2O2-x, and two snapshots at 5.0 and 10.0 ps, respectively. As can be seen from Fig. 1d, the B atom is stably embedded in the O vacancy of B@Mo3C2O2-x, and the geometric structures of B@Mo3C2O2-x is preserved well within 10 ps. Therefore, this indicates that the catalysts have high thermodynamic stability. The partial density of states (PDOS) of B@M3C2O2-x as plotted in Fig. S3 shows that the B doped SACs exhibit metallic characteristic, which provides a prerequisite for rapid electron transfer between catalyst and reactant. The states near the Fermi level are mainly attributed to the hybrid of the TM-d and B-p orbitals, which indicates the bond between TM and B atoms. Catalyst screening NRR is a six-electron reduction reaction, N2+ 6(H+ + e-) → 2NH3. The reaction process includes N2-adsorption (step 1) and six reduction elementary reactions. Obviously, N2 adsorption is the first step during NRR process and plays a key role in the whole reaction. A good candidate catalyst must have sufficient adsorption stability for N2 molecule so that the inert NN triple bond can be effectively activated. N2 molecules have two adsorption configurations, i.e., end-on and side-on configurations (Fig. 2 a). The corresponding adsorption energies of the optimized configurations on B@M3C3O2-x are shown in Fig. 2b. It is seen that N2 molecules are preferentially adsorbed on B@M3C3O2-x through the end-on mode. The adsorption energy ranges from -1.59 to -0.81 eV, indicating N2 molecules are firmly bonded to B atoms, which is a spontaneous exothermic process under ambient conditions. In order to reveal the adsorption nature of N2 on SACs, the Bader charge analysis was performed. The results show that electrons are transferred from the catalysts to the adsorbed *N2, and it is found that there is a good linear relationship between the N-N bond length and the Bader charge of N2 absorbed on B@M3C2O2-x. As shown in Fig. 3 a, with the increase of the charge accumulation on N2, the N-N bond length becomes longer, which weakens the NN triple bond and is favorable to the activation of N2. Furthermore, taking B@M3C2O2-x (M=V, Cr, Nb, Mo, W) as examples, the orbital interaction between the active center B atom and N2 is deeply analyzed by calculating the partial density of states. The PDOS of B-2p and N2 molecular orbitals is plotted in Fig. 3b (Fig. S4a-d). As can be seen from Fig. 3b, the empty 2p orbitals of B accept electrons from the 2π and 3σ orbitals of N2 molecule to form the bonding states; meanwhile, the occupied p orbitals of B back-donate electrons to the 2π* orbital of N2 molecule. Thus the NN triple bond is greatly weakened and the B-N bond is strengthened. The charge density difference shown in Fig. 3c (and Fig. S5) further confirms such acceptance and donation effect between B and N2. Therefore, B@M3C2O2-x (M=V, Cr, Nb, Mo, W) catalysts can effectively activate N2 molecule. It is known that different initial adsorption configurations lead to different NRR mechanisms [37–38]. Generally, starting from the end-on adsorption of N2, NRR takes place via distal, alternating or mixed mechanisms, while the side-on adsorption corresponds to consecutive and enzymatic mechanisms. Thus, in the following study, the distal, alternating and mixed mechanisms were considered on these nine SACs. Regardless of the mechanism, the first protonation step of *N2 + H+ + e- → *NNH and the last protonation step of *NH2 + H+ + e- → *NH3 will occur, and for many catalysts, the potential determining step (PDS) is usually one of these two steps, that is, this step is most thermodynamically uphill step in the whole reduction process. Thus, in order to quickly screen out candidates catalysts with high catalytic activity from the nine B@M3C3O2-x SACs, we adopted the two-step strategy proposed by Wang et al. [39] and used the free energy change of the above two steps (i.e., ∆G* N2- * NNH and ∆G* NH2- * NH3) as the activity descriptors [40–49]. In this study, the criteria of these two descriptors is set to 0.70 eV. The free energy changes of these two protonation steps are shown in Fig. 4 . The results show that B@Zr3C2O2-x, B@Hf3C2O2-x and B@Ti3C2O2-x can be excluded, while the other six SACs, B@M3C2O2-x, (M= V, Cr, Nb, Mo, Ta, W), meet the criteria, which may be the promising candidates for NRR. In addition, under experimental conditions, the adsorption of H2O on the surface active sites will hinder N2 adsorption, thus reducing the possibility of NRR [50]. Therefore, we also compared the adsorption energy of H2O and N2 on the other six B@M3C2O2-x. As shown in Table S2, the adsorption energy of N2 is more negative than that of H2O, indicating that the surface active sites of these catalysts will not be blocked by H2O molecules. In order to further prove the adsorption advantage of N2 on H2O, taking B@V3C2O2-x as an example, we further performed the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations in the case of simultaneous presence of N2 and H2O molecules. According to the AIMD study on the interaction energy between N2 and H2O on the surface of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) for NRR by Chen et al, it is found that when the ratio of 125N2/75H2O was used in the model system, the maximum interaction energy was obtained [51]. Based on their results, we adopted the same N2/H2O ratio. Here, 5 N2 and 3 H2O molecules were considered in our present simulation system. As shown in Fig. S6, the results show that N2 molecule has stronger adsorption energy than H2O and preferentially adsorbs on B atom. Hydrogen bonds can be formed between H2O molecules and the oxygen termination of B@V3C2O2-x. In addition, it is seen that H+ in H2O combine with N2 to form NNH intermediate, which further forms NNH2 intermediate. NRR mechanism on B@M3C2O2-x To accurately evaluate the NRR catalytic performance on B@M3C2O2-x, three possible NRR mechanisms including distal, alternating and mixed mechanisms were calculated and shown in Scheme 1 . In the distal mechanism, the proton-electron pairs continuously react with the N atom far away from the active center until release of the first NH3 and then hydrogenation continues to occur to form the second NH3 molecule. In the alternating mechanism, the proton-electron pairs alternately react with two N atoms, releasing two NH3 molecules simultaneously at the end of the reaction [52–53]. Mixed mechanism is transition between distal mechanism and alternating mechanism. Figs. 5 a-f summarizes the free energy changes of each elementary reaction along the NRR pathways on the B@M3C2O2-x (M=V, Cr, Nb, Mo, Ta, W) and the corresponding intermediate configurations are shown in Figs. S7-S12. Three different reaction pathways are represented in the Fig. 5 (the different parts are highlighted with a yellow background). There are similar reaction pathways on B@Nb3C2O2-x (Fig. 5a) and B@Ta3C2O2-x (Fig. 5b). Seen from Fig. 5a, the adsorption free energy of N2 is -0.81 eV. The first (H+ + e-) pair attacks the remote N site of N2 to form a *NNH intermediate. The ΔG value of the first hydrogenation step is 0.23 eV. From the *NNH intermediate, the formation of *NNH2 is a downhill process, with the free energy change of -0.51 eV, while the formation of *NHNH is an uphill process, with the free energy change of 0.63 eV. So forming *NNH2 is more energetically advantageous. Subsequently, the H+ + e- pair is easier to combine with the proximal N atom of *NNH2 to form *NHNH2 with the ΔG value of 0.13 eV, while the *NNH2 + H+ + e- → *NNH3 is endothermic by 0.56 eV. Similarly, the fourth hydrogenation step may give products *NHNH3 or *NH2NH2. Obviously, *NHNH3 is easily to be formed with the ΔG value of -0.41 eV. The fifth protonation step of *NHNH3 produces the first NH3 and *NH2 intermediates, and then the last protonation step of *NH2 forms the second *NH3. The ΔG values of these two steps are -1.58 and 0.45 eV, respectively. The results show that NRR proceeds via a mixed mechanism on B@Nb3C2O2-x. The (H+ + e-) pair transfer step of *NH2 (*NH2 + H+ + e- → *NH3) is the PDS of B@Nb3C2O2-x. The limiting potential is -0.45 V, indicating that B@Nb3C2O2-x catalyst has a high NRR catalytic activity. Note that the release of NH3 is endothermic by about 1.81 eV. However, in the acidic solution, NH3 molecules are easily desorbed from the surface to form NH4 +, as demonstrated in previous reports [54–56]. The Gibbs free energy changes along the reaction pathway of eNRR through a mixed mechanism on B@V3C2O2-x and B@Mo3C2O2-x are shown in Figs. 5c and 5d. The first three hydrogenation steps are similar to those on B@Nb3C2O2-x to form *NHNH2, i.e., *N2 → *NNH → *NNH2 → *NHNH2; while in the fourth protonation step, the first *NH3 molecule is desorbed to form *NH intermediate, which is different from that *NHNH2 forms *NHNH3 intermediate on B@Nb3C2O2-x. The PDS is the first protonation step on these two SACs, with the limiting potentials of -0.32 and -0.39 V, respectively. Figs. 5e and 5f show the free energy diagrams of NRR on B@Cr3C2O2-x and B@W3C2O2-x. The NRR process on these two catalysts also proceed through a mixed pathway. The part of reaction pathway different from the above four catalysts is *NHNH2 → *NHNH3 → *NH. Likewise, *N2 + H+ + e- → *NNH process on these two catalysts is PDS with Gibbs free energy change of 0.40 and 0.48 eV. The above calculation results show that B@M3C2O2-x (M=V, Cr, Nb, Mo, Ta and W) exhibit high catalytic activity for NRR, with UL ranging from -0.32 V to -0.69 V. Particularly, B@V3C2O2-x with the least negative U L value (-0.32 V) shows better NRR activity than some previously reported TM SACs with MXene as support, such as Ti@Mo2CO2 (-0.64 V) [19], Co/Ti3C2O2 (-0.56 V) [27], Rh/Ti3C2O2 (-0.80 V) [27], and is comparable to the catalytic activity of B-doped MXene SACs, such as B/Mo2CO2 (-0.20 V) [25], B/W2CO2 (-0.24 V) [25], B@Nb4C3O2 (-0.26 V) [57] and B@Ti3N2O2 (-0.10 V) [57]. Competing reaction between NRR and HER on B@M3C2O2-x catalysts For ideal NRR electrocatalysts, in addition to good stability and activity, catalytic selectivity is also of paramount important factor to be considered. The proton-electron pairs required for NRR are provided by aqueous solution, and H+ is easy to cover the metal surface. Therefore, HER is the main competing side reaction, which leads to poor NRR selectivity and low Faraday efficiency [58–59]. Here, we compared the adsorption Gibbs free energies of N2 and H (ΔG *N2 and ΔG *H) on the surfaces of six SACs. As schematically illustrated in Fig. 6 a, ΔG *N2 is more negative than ΔG *H indicating that N2 is more favorable for adsorption on these B@M3C2O2-x than H, so it is conductive to the NRR process. Furthermore, we qualitatively evaluated the competition between the two reactions by comparing the limiting potentials U L(NRR) and U L(HER). When the value of U L(NRR)-U L(HER) is positive, NRR selectivity is better than HER, on the contrary, HER selectivity is higher [60]. As shown in Fig. 6b, except for B@Ta3C2O2-x with the U L(NRR)-U L(HER) value of -0.12 V, the other five B@M3C2O2-x (M=V, Cr, Nb, Mo, W) have positive values of 0.65, 0.64, 0.08, 0.16 and 0.43 V, respectively, indicating that they have high NRR activity and selectivity and may be promising NRR catalysts. The origin of NRR high catalytic activity on B@M3C2O2-x To reveal the origin of NRR activity on these five catalysts (B@M3C2O2-x, M=V, Cr, Nb, Mo, W), we calculated the d-band centers (εd ) of three metal atoms around B atom and the p-band center (εp ) of B atom. Fig. 7 presents the relationship between the limiting potential and the band center difference ( Δ ε = ε d − ε p ). It can be seen that U L and Δ ε exhibits a volcano-type curve, where the value of Δ ε (-1.06 eV) of B@V3C2O2-x is around the top of the volcano-type curve, indicating that B@V3C2O2-x has the highest activity among all the considered B@M3C2O2-x. Our results show that the interaction between the active center and the substrate has a great influence on the catalytic performance of NRR. Electron transfer can reflect the activation degree of each intermediate, so it has an important effect on NRR electrocatalytic activity. We carried out the charge variation of each intermediate in NRR process along dominant pathway. These reaction intermediates can be divided into three parts, including the adsorbed NxHy intermediate (part 3), BM3 (M3 = three surrounding metal atoms, part 2) and B@M3C2O2-x without BM3 (M =V, Cr, Nb, Mo, W, part 1). As shown in Fig. 8 (and Fig. S13a-d), the three parts have charge fluctuations during the whole NRR process, and the charge transfer mainly occurs on part 1 and part 2. When N2 is adsorbed, N2 molecule obtains 0.46, 0.42, 0.55, 0.41 and 0.44 electrons from B@V3C2O2-x, B@Cr3C2O2-x, B@Nb3C2O2-x, B@Mo3C2O2-x and B@W3C2O2-x catalysts, respectively, and the electrons are mainly provided by part 2. This phenomenon suggests that BM3 act as intermediate station for rapid charge transfer between part 1 and part 3 and act as the active center responsible for activating N2. The M3C2O2-x substrate serves as an electron storage for receiving and donating electrons. Accordingly, part 1 and part 2 have synergetic effect on the activation of N2, and they combine to form promising NRR catalysts with low limiting potential. Conclusion The potential of B atom anchored on M3C2O2-x (M= Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W) as NRR electrocatalysts has been systematically studied by using density functional theory. The electronic structure analysis reveals the “acceptance-donation” interaction mechanism between the B active center and *N2. Using the adsorption free energy of N2 and free energy changes for the first and last electrochemical steps as the screening strategy, six catalysts (B@M3C2O2-x, M= V, Cr, Nb, Mo, W and Ta) were screened out, of which B@Ta3C2O2-x was excluded due to its high HER selectivity. The present calculations show that NRR proceeds via the mixed mechanism on the remaining five SACs, with the limiting potentials ranging from -0.32 V to -0.48 V. Among them, B@V3C2O2-x exhibit excellent NRR catalytic performance. AIMD simulation shows that these potential NRR electrocatalysts have high thermodynamic stability, so they are expected to be synthesized in experiments. We hope that our work will stimulate experimental and theoretical studies of non-metal doped MXene catalysts to explore the potential of MXenes in NRR and other electrocatalytic reactions. coredata.dc:description: The design of efficient catalysts plays an important role in the development of electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). 2D materials MXene can be used as promising catalyst substrates in NRR due to their superior chemical stability and conductivity. Here, using density functional theory calculations, 9 kinds of single-atom catalysts (SACs) B@M3C2O2-x (M = Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W) were constructed by anchoring electron-deficient non-metal boron atom on M3C2O2-x with one terminal-O vacancy. All SACs have good thermodynamic and electrochemical stability. The strong acceptor-donor interaction between B atom and N2 molecule leads to the activation of N2, thus promoting NRR. We adopted the screening strategies, including comparing the free energy of N2 adsorption, the free energy changes for the first and last electrochemical steps of NRR, and the selectivity of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Finally, five candidate catalysts (B@V3C2O2-x, B@Cr3C2O2-x, B@Nb3C2O2-x, B@Mo3C2O2-x and B@W3C2O2-x) were screened out. Starting from the end-on adsorption mode of N2, NRR proceeds through a mixed mechanism on each SAC. Our results show that these five SACs have excellent catalytic performance with the limiting potentials ranging from -0.32 to -0.48 V, which may be promising NRR electrocatalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Prediction of single-boron anchored on MXene catalysts for high-efficient electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction
